files.name: president-letter-1975-03.pdf.ref.json
files.content:
Office of the President
March 15, 1975

To the University Community,

I write to inform you of several important developments affecting our institution.

First, the Board of Trustees has approved a comprehensive renovation of the Science Building, funded through a generous donation from the Alumni Association. Construction will begin this summer.

Second, I am pleased to announce that enrollment for Fall 1975 has reached a record 4,500 students, representing a 15% increase over last year.

Finally, we welcome three new faculty members to the Department of Computer Science, reflecting our commitment to emerging technologies.

Sincerely,
Dr. Robert Henderson
President

files.name: graduation-program.pdf.ref.json
files.content:
COMMENCEMENT EXERCISES
May 25, 1975

ORDER OF EVENTS

10:00 AM - Processional
10:15 AM - Welcome by President Henderson
10:30 AM - Commencement Address
           "Technology and the Human Spirit"
           by Dr. Margaret Chen, IBM Research
11:15 AM - Conferring of Degrees
           Bachelor of Arts: 342 graduates
           Bachelor of Science: 298 graduates
           Master's Degrees: 87 graduates
           Doctoral Degrees: 12 graduates
12:30 PM - Recessional

Total Graduates: 739

files.name: faculty-senate-minutes-1975-04.pdf.ref.json
files.content:
FACULTY SENATE MEETING MINUTES
April 18, 1975

Present: 45 voting members

OLD BUSINESS
1. Curriculum Review Committee presented proposed changes to general education requirements. Motion to approve passed 32-8.

2. Parking Committee reported ongoing challenges with limited spaces. Proposal to build new parking structure tabled pending cost analysis.

NEW BUSINESS
1. Proposal for new Computer Science major approved unanimously.

2. Discussion of tenure procedures. Committee formed to review current policies.

3. Budget concerns raised regarding library acquisitions. President Henderson committed to addressing in next fiscal year.

Meeting adjourned 4:30 PM.

Next meeting: May 16, 1975

files.name: research-grant-announcement.pdf.ref.json
files.content:
RESEARCH GRANT AWARD

The National Science Foundation has awarded $450,000 to Dr. Sarah Williams, Department of Biology, for her research project "Microbial Ecology in Freshwater Systems."

This three-year grant will support:
- Two graduate research assistants
- Laboratory equipment
- Field research in local lake systems
- Conference travel and publication costs

This is the largest single research grant in the university's history.

Dr. Williams' research examines the role of microorganisms in maintaining water quality and has significant implications for environmental management.

The grant period runs from September 1975 through August 1978.

files.name: student-newspaper-1975-05.pdf.ref.json
files.content:
THE CAMPUS HERALD
May 1, 1975

HEADLINES

"Record Enrollment Expected for Fall"
Admissions office reports 15% increase in applications.

"Computer Lab Opens in Science Building"
Students gain access to PDP-11 minicomputer.

"Women's Basketball Team Wins Conference Championship"
First conference title in school history.

"Library Hours Extended During Finals Week"
24-hour access May 15-22.

EDITORIAL
"On the Need for Better Campus Lighting"
Safety concerns raised about poorly lit pathways.

OPINION
"Is Technology Making Us Less Human?"
Student reflects on increasing computerization.

DEPARTMENT OF ATHLETICS

Basketball (Women): 22-3 (conference: 12-0) - CHAMPIONS

Track & Field: 3rd place conference

PARTICIPATION
Varsity Athletes: 285
Intramural Participants: 1,240

FACILITIES
Stadium Capacity: 8,500
Gymnasium Capacity: 2,200
Training Facilities: Recently upgraded

NOTABLE ACHIEVEMENTS
- Women's Basketball Conference Championship
- 3 All-Conference selections
- 1 Academic All-American

files.name: collection-notes.md
files.content:
# 1975 University Archives Collection

This collection documents a significant year in the university's history, marked by growth, achievement, and modernization.

## Key Events

- Record enrollment (4,500 students)
- Major research grant award ($450,000 NSF grant)
- Science Building renovation announced
- Women's Basketball conference championship
- Introduction of Computer Science major
- Commencement: 739 graduates

## Document Types

- Administrative correspondence
- Financial reports
- Faculty governance minutes
- Student publications
- Athletic records
- Photographs
- Architectural plans

## Historical Context

Mid-1970s marked transition period:
- Increasing enrollment following post-Vietnam era
- Growing emphasis on technology and computer science
- Expansion of women's athletics
- Financial stability through diversified revenue sources

## Themes

- Institutional growth and development
- Academic innovation (Computer Science)
- Athletics achievement
- Financial management
- Campus development
